channel.title: theory on Schulich Ignite
channel.description: Recent content in theory on Schulich Ignite

item.title: Making Things Small
item.description: Compression is the art of taking some data and making it smaller. If you want more details about common compression schemes take a look at our definition page for compression.

item.title: The power of paths
item.description: A path is a way to something. It’s how we go from what we know, and where we are, to what we want to know, and where we want to go.

item.title: Datastructures in C++
item.description: By now you should have a decent understanding of classes and objects. If not, go check out our blog post on the topic to see what I’m talking about.

item.title: Making categories simpler
item.description: Why is a wolf different than a jellyfish? There are obvious differences, but how do we categorize something as more wolfey, or more jellyfishy?

item.title: It's caches all the way down
item.description: Nostalgia can be very powerful, looking back at the world can make people feel warm and fuzzy inside. However, one thing people are not nostalgic of is how long computers used to take to do things.

item.title: How to Write Pseudocode
item.description: Perhaps you have taken a computer science course, and you heard the term “pseudocode” used at some point. If you have ever wondered what this is, here is the guide for you.
Classes are a programming construct that allows you to organize your code. Essentially you create a class which acts as a kind of template which you can then create instances/objects out of.
